item.title: Regression Analysis: How Do I Interpret R-squared and Assess the Goodness-of-Fit?
item.description: After you have fit a linear model using regression analysis, ANOVA, or design of experiments (DOE), you need to determine how well the model fits the data. In this post, weâ€™ll explore the R-squared (R2 ) statistic, some of its limitations, and uncover some surprises along the way. For instance, low R-squared values are not always bad and high R-squared values are not always good!

item.title: How to Interpret a Regression Model with Low R-squared and Low P values
item.description: In regression analysis, you’d like your regression model to have significant variables and to produce a high R-squared value. This low P value and high $R^2$ combination indicates that changes in the predictors are related to changes in the response variable and that your model explains a lot of the response variability.
